Would you like me to also show you how to make this setup work automatically for pages inside subfolders (like /tokyoDays/tokyo1.html) so you dont have to manually change the fetch() path for each one?

You said:
what about the html tags thata re in subfolders, what should their script be for navbar js
ChatGPT said:

Excellent question this is exactly the tricky part that trips people up when moving files into folders.

Lets go over it clearly and step-by-step

Your current folder setup (assumed)

arduino
project/

 home.html
 japan.css
 images/
    ...
 navbar/
    navbar.html
    navbar.js
 tokyoDays/
    tokyoFirst.html
    tokyoChichibu.html
    tokyoSecond.html
 kyotoOsaka/
     Kyoto.html
     Osaka.html
     ...

The problem

When you use:

js
fetch("navbar/navbar.html")

It works for files in the root folder (like home.html),
but not for files inside subfolders
because tokyoDays/tokyoFirst.html will try to fetch:

bash
tokyoDays/navbar/navbar.html

(which doesnt exist).

The universal solution

We can make the navbar.js smart enough to detect where its being loaded from and automatically use the correct relative path.

Update your navbar/navbar.js to this:

js
document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", () => {
  // Determine the correct path to navbar.html
  const depth = window.location.pathname.split("/").length - 2; // number of subfolders
  const prefix = "../".repeat(depth); // go up folders as needed
  const navbarPath = `${prefix}navbar/navbar.html`;

  fetch(navbarPath)
    .then(response => {
      if (!response.ok) throw new Error(`HTTP error! status: ${response.status}`);
      return response.text();
    })
    .then(data => {
      document.getElementById("navbar-container").innerHTML = data;
      console.log(" Navbar loaded from:", navbarPath);
      setActiveLink();
      setupMobileDropdowns();
    })
    .catch(error => console.error(" Error loading navbar:", error));
});

function myFunction() {
  const x = document.getElementById("myTopnav");
  x.classList.toggle("responsive");
}

function setActiveLink() {
  const currentPage = window.location.pathname.split("/").pop();
  const links = document.querySelectorAll("#myTopnav a");

  links.forEach(link => {
    const linkPage = link.getAttribute("href");
    if (linkPage && currentPage && linkPage.includes(currentPage)) {
      link.classList.add("active");
      const parentDropdown = link.closest(".dropdown");
      if (parentDropdown) {
        const button = parentDropdown.querySelector(".dropbtn");
        if (button) button.classList.add("active");
      }
    } else {
      link.classList.remove("active");
    }
  });
}

function setupMobileDropdowns() {
  const dropdowns = document.querySelectorAll(".dropdown .dropbtn");

  dropdowns.forEach(btn => {
    btn.addEventListener("click", e => {
      e.preventDefault();
      const parentDropdown = btn.parentElement;
      parentDropdown.classList.toggle("active");
    });
  });
}

Then, in your HTML pages

In root pages (like home.html)

html
<script src="navbar/navbar.js" defer></script>

In subfolder pages (like tokyoDays/tokyoFirst.html)

html
<script src="../navbar/navbar.js" defer></script>

Thats all you need to change.
The JS automatically calculates how far up it needs to go to reach /navbar/navbar.html.

Quick check

When you open the browser console:

  • On home.html, you should see:

    bash
     Navbar loaded from: navbar/navbar.html

  • On tokyoDays/tokyoFirst.html, you should see:

    bash
     Navbar loaded from: ../navbar/navbar.html

If you see that, everythings working perfectly.

Ah, I see! Based on the screenshot you uploaded, your navbar looks very faded and the dropdowns arent showing properly. That usually happens when the CSS for the navbar is overridden or the HTML structure isnt what the CSS expects.

Heres how to restore it to the previous version behavior you had:

1 Restore navbar background and link colors

css
.topnav {
  overflow: visible;
  background-color: black;  /* make navbar solid black */
  position: fixed;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  width: 100%;
  z-index: 1000;
}

.topnav a {
  float: left;
  display: block;
  color: #f2f2f2;          /* white links */
  text-align: center;
  padding: 14px 16px;
  text-decoration: none;
  font-size: 17px;
}

.topnav a:hover {
  background-color: pink;   /* pink highlight */
  color: black;
}

.topnav a.active {
  background-color: red;
  color: white;
}

2 Desktop dropdown hover

css
.dropdown:hover .dropdown-content {
  display: block;         /* show dropdown when hovering */
}

.dropdown:hover .dropbtn {
  background-color: red;
  color: white;
}

3 Dropdown content styling

css
.dropdown-content {
  display: none;
  position: absolute;
  top: 100%;
  left: 0;
  background-color: #333;  /* dark gray dropdown */
  min-width: 160px;
  box-shadow: 0px 8px 16px rgba(0,0,0,0.3);
  z-index: 1001;
}

.dropdown-content a {
  float: none;
  color: #f2f2f2;         /* white links */
  padding: 12px 16px;
  text-decoration: none;
  display: block;
  text-align: left;
}

.dropdown-content a:hover {
  background-color: pink;
  color: black;
}

4 Mobile click behavior

css
@media screen and (max-width: 1000px) {
  .topnav a:not(:first-child),
  .dropdown .dropbtn { display: none; }

  .topnav a.icon { float: right; display: block; }

  .topnav.responsive { position: relative; }
  .topnav.responsive .icon { position: absolute; right: 0; top: 0; }

  .topnav.responsive a { float: none; display: block; text-align: left; }

  .topnav.responsive .dropdown { float: none; width: 100%; }

  .topnav.responsive .dropdown-content { position: relative; display: none; }

  .topnav.responsive .dropdown.active .dropdown-content {
    display: block;   /* show on click */
  }

  .topnav.responsive .dropdown .dropbtn {
    display: block;
    width: 100%;
    text-align: left;
  }
}
